newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - U.S. technology trade publications.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - U.S. technology trade publications.

text.p: For the week of Oct. 7, here are some of the top stories reported in major U.S. technology trade publications.

ELECTRONIC ENGINEERING TIMES - Taking aim at Microsoft Corp's dominance of the computer operating systems market, Japanese consumer electronics giants are quietly working together to select one standardized real-time operating system that can be used across product categories, EE Times reported in its Oct. 7 issue.

COMPUTER RESELLER NEWS - Intel Corp has set up development teams to work on new Internet appliances even as its executives continue to ridicule prospects for such low-cost network computers as advocated by Oracle Corp's Chief Executive Larry Ellison, CRN reported in its Oct. 7 issue.

But while Intel appears to be at least acknowledging the viability of slimmed down network computers, Microsoft Corp is planning to offer an increasingly larger Windows 97 operating system that integrates its Internet Explorer browser, Simply Interactive features for making PCs more like consumer electronics and much of the software its includes in current versions of the Microsoft Office applications suite.

PC WEEK - International Business Machines Corp is making a new push to unify leading UNIX software makers to adopt a common set of programming standards in an effort to stem the inroads Microsoft Corp's Windows NT is making against UNIX, PC Week reported in its October 7 issue.

INFOWORLD - Unix vendors with the notable exception of Sun Microsystems Inc are beginning to promote products for mixed systems that include Microsoft Corp's rapidly growing Windows NT offering, Infoworld reported in its Oct. 7 issue.

A proposal aimed at clearing congestion on the Internet would require Internet service providers to pay each other for helping to route traffic, providing an incentive to move to a more simplified routing protocol.

INFORMATION WEEK - Facing competition from International Business Machines Corp's and Corel Corp, Microsoft is offering new license agreements for its Office suite that include volume discounts on a sliding scale, Information Week reported in its Oct. 7 issue.
Big database vendors including Oracle Corp., IBM and NCR have plans to port parallel versions of their systems to Microsoft's Windows NT platform, Information Week reported.

COMMUNICATIONS WEEK - AT&T Corp's Wide Area Network (WAN) service designed to link together corporate local area networks running Novell Inc Netware has failed to generate much enthusiasm among customers, who are confused about its value compared to similar Internet-based services, the magazine reported in its Oct. 7 issue.
The magazine also reported that basic Web browsers are rapidly becoming the preferred front-ends for corporate developers seeking to develop enterprise wide applications.

COMPUTERWORLD - Sun Microsystems plans to unveil its first Java-based network computers Oct. 29, the magazine reported in its Oct. 7 issue. The company plans to showcase a dozen large corporate customers who plan to purchase the stripped-down computer devices.

COMPUTER RETAIL WEEK - Software publishers are increasingly moving to expand product sales directly to customers via the Internet, Computer Retail Week reported in its Oct. 7 issue. But retailers believe that the new medium pose little threat to them as consumers are not yet comfortable ordering software over the Web in large numbers. A week ago, SoftKey International joined CUC International Inc, Broderbund Software Inc, Maxis Inc and Quarterdeck Corp, who already offer Web-based software outlets.

ELECTRONIC BUYERS' NEWS - Intel Corp is wielding its power as the dominant maker of the microprocessor brains which control personal computers to demand that makers of three-dimensional graphic chips help it boost the graphics performance of PCs ten-fold within the nex three years, the magazine reported in its Oct. 7 edition.
